body_content.explanation:
past simple and past participle of 
swallow
to cause food, drink, pills, etc. to move from your mouth into your stomach by using the muscles of your throat:
examples: My throat is so sore that it really hurts when I swallow.
He put a grape into his mouth and swallowed it whole.

body_content.explanation: to use the muscles of your throat, as if moving something from your mouth into your stomach, because you are nervous or frightened, or are about to say something:
examples: He swallowed hard and said, "Dad, I have something to tell you."

body_content.explanation: If something large swallows (up) another thing, it makes it disappear or stop existing separately by making it part of itself:
examples: An increasing amount of the countryside is being swallowed (up) by the town.
Many small businesses have been swallowed (up) by large companies.

body_content.explanation: to use or take away a large part of something valuable:
examples: Taxes have swallowed up nearly half of my pay increase.

body_content.explanation: to accept something without question or without expressing disagreement:
examples: Not surprisingly, this excuse was too much for them to swallow.
She swallowed his sales pitch hook, line, and sinker (= believed it completely).

body_content.explanation: to not express or show something:
examples: She swallowed her disappointment, saying, "That's OK, it doesn't matter."
